etymologies: early 18th century: from French, from Latin assonare ‘respond to’, from ad- ‘to’ + sonare (from sonus ‘sound’)

definitions: in poetry, the repetition of the sound of a vowel or diphthong in nonrhyming stressed syllables near enough to each other for the echo to be discernible (e.g., penitence, reticence)

examples.text: the use of assonance throughout the poem creates the sound of despair
alliterative assonances such as “fail” and “fall” are very common in Old English poetry

shortDefinitions: resemblance of sound between syllables of nearby words, arising particularly from rhyming of two or more stressed vowels
